SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering the questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who has lived in this province will have exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer; you need not worry about leaving blank spaces. If you feel unable to answer the questions, or if there are particular areas which you would like to describe in detail, or if you have any other questions, please put them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who have lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires:

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Pioneers: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Gain?" is still being circulated. If you haven't already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 2, entitled "Pioneer Life: What Would You Have Done Differently?" is still being circulated. If you haven't already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

Preservation of Questionnaires:

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Branch Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent records of our province. Please send your completed Questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the reader:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your own experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so leaving blank spaces. It is suggested that you try to answer the questions to the best of your knowledge and ability.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or reply for a separate questionnaire.

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you rather have someone else do the writing for you, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name .............................................. Otto, Sorsdahl

2. Your address .................................................. Miala, Saskatchewan

3. Date ................................................................. August 25, 1962

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country)
   Kingsbury County, De Smet, South Dakota, U.S.A.

5. What was your father's name and occupation?
   Andrew S. Sorsdahl, plasterer but later took up farming.

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year)
   May 4, 1905

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.
   Castlewood, South Dakota 1901

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc.)

9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   Other members of the family were coming and it looked like a good opportunity for a teenager to go to a new country. I wanted to fill on a homestead.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)
    My brother and brother-in-law had been to Saskatchewan the year before and they came back with encouraging reports as to the farming possibilities of this new province. My interest was kindled and I decided when they would return to Saskatchewan, I would accompany them.
1. Your full name ........................................... Orla Dorsdal

2. Your address ........................................... Minot, North Dakota

3. Date ......................................................... August 6, 1958

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country) Klugburg County, North Dakota, U.S.A.

5. What was your father's name and occupation? Andrew S. Dorsdal, farmer but later took up farming.

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year) May 4, 1905

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible. Oakville, South Dakota 1901

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was in my teens," etc.)

9. What were your reasons for coming West? Other members of this family were coming and it looked like a good opportunity for a teenager to go to a new country. I wanted to file on a homestead.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it?) My brother and brother-in-law had been to Saskatchewan the year before and they came back with encouraging reports as to the farming possibilities of this new province. My interest was kindled and I decided when they would return to Saskatchewan, if too would accompany them.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? The younger members of the family thought it was a ridiculous idea to leave our home in South Dakota to travel to such a little known place as Saskatchewan, but one brother was as enthusiastic as I was.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)? My brother and I came up on an immigrant train. He had two cars loaded with settlers' effects, horses, machinery etc.

13. What means of transportation did you use? Came by rail.

14. What incidents of the journey best do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.) We were on the train nine or eleven days making one train change. We were on a train packed with immigrants coming from the Dakotas, Minnesota and a number of other states. In my eagerness to get here, I am afraid my only impression was the vibrations of the train. We often got out to walk and had no difficulty in catching up with the train sometime later.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? I got off at St. Leon and stayed with my brother about four miles south of the hamlet.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? On a homestead about twenty-one miles west of Lacombe and fifteen miles south west of Miallo. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

17. You on the homestead until 1927 then on a farm two miles out of Miallo. In 1936 I retired to Middle Village.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came? Laborer, mostly assisting on farms. Since coming to Saskatchewan I have been occupied in farming.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

The younger members of the family thought it was a ridiculous idea to leave our home in South Dakota to travel to such a little-known place as Saskatchewan.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends, or other group)?

My brother and I came up on an Inglewood train. He had two cars loaded with all our effects, horses, machinery, etc.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Gone by rail.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

We were on the train nine or eleven days making one train change. We were on a train packed with lumber coming from the Dakotas, Minnesota, and a number of other states. In my eagerness to get here, I got off at my only stopless lot was the elevation of the train. We often got out to walk and had no difficulty in catching up with the train sometime later.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

I got off at Macoun and stayed with my brother about four miles south of the hamlet.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? About how many acres?

On a homestead about fifteen miles west of Macoun and fifteen miles south west of Macoun.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

This was our homestead until 1927 then on a farm two miles out of Macoun.

In 1935 I retired to Middle Village.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How about you now?

Laborer mostly assisting on farms. Since coming to Saskatchewan I have been occupied in farming.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home? Only occasionally.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation?

22. Tell when they came and where they settled.

23. Is there any particular experiences of pioneer days that stand out in your memory which you would like to record?

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? By what means of travel?

25. We visited our neighbors, but as they were settled fairly close to us we did not have to make any long trips. We used a horse and buggy to go when necessary.

24. What kind of wild animals which one does not see today? In the spring of 1865, we happened to be in Laramie, about 67 miles from Miles City, and a band of Indians, who had been living in a very primitive manner near Butte, had been arrested for rustling horses. Our party was very sorry that we were in charge of them. They had to stay in Butte overnight.

25. Tell us why the Indians were arrested. We believe it was because they stole horses.

26. Had you traveled much in the early years? (For instance, by stagecoach, train, walking, etc.) How often? By what means of conveyance?

27. Would you recommend our neighbors, both as they were settled fairly close to us and did not have to make any long trips. It used to be quite a journey to go west.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new terms appear-

Have continued to trade at Mitlee

29. How often did you shop in the early days?

Once a week

30. Then (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly

Saturday shopping began right from the beginning of the settling

in our district. It is still the big night of the week.

31. What kind of articles did you buy in this way? (Indicate also what fraction of

your local purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of

mail order catalogues, either then or now, as I prefer to buy

products which I have first seen.

Mail ordering was in existence very early but this was not an

important factor in buying. It constituted a very small per-

centage of the purchasing. I have made very little use of the

mail order catalogues, either then or now, as I prefer to buy

products which I have first seen.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

1912. This was the first rural telephone line built in this entire

district. It was the Lao Qui Parle Telephone Line. It was and is a

permanent fixture. Or did you make it yourself after trying it out? When did you

settle, it began to look more promising and after I had established

my own home we decided to stay.

   In 1913, a Ford purchased by the banker in Misale and another by

5. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1924? What reasons?

34. Did any people have for moving?

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return?

A number left to go north but several of them returned and are still residing in this district.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public offices, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

I was a member of the local School Board and Secretary treasurer from its beginning until moving to town. I was also a member of the Municipal school Board from 1926 to 1936 and served for X years on the Municipal Council of County.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here, giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combining organizing the first lodge, etc.)

I was instrumental in organizing the Sorsdahl school district in 1912 a district which was named after our family.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post offices, villages, railway stations, trees, hills, etc.) Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name; (2) origin and meaning of the name; (3) date of its adoption; (4) any changes in names since the first time was given; date and reason for change. Give fruits of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

Because such a large number of Sorsdahl families, all relatives, settled and grew up in the district the Sorsdahl school was named.

The Leo Qua Parle telephone Company was named because so many of the residents of the district came from Leo Qua Parle county in Minnesota.

The Leo Qua Parle school district derived its name in the same way.

The Village of Goodwater, just south of our homestead and a place we often visited was so named because excellent water was so plentiful.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons?

35. Did many people move away during the 1920s? Did many return? A number left to go north but several of them returned and are still residing in this district.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public offices or have been connected with the municipal school board or any other organization for the purpose of improving the welfare of your town, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

I was instrumental in organizing the Sorsdahl school district in 1912 and served as its first president until 1918.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates whenever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

I was the first to own a telephone in our town.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post offices, villages, railway stations, trees, hills, etc.) Try to give (1) name, (2) date of adoption, (3) reason for adoption, (4) any changes in names since then, (5) date and reason for change.

Because such a large number of Sorsdahl families, all relatives, settled and grew up in the district the Sorsdahl school was named.

The Leo Qua Parke telephone company was named because so many of the residents of the district came from Leo Qua Perle county in Minnesota.

The Leo Qua Parke school district derived its name in this same way.

The village of Godstater, just south of our homestead and a place we often visited was so named because excellent water was so plentiful.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

The coming of the automobile and the radio. The power machinery which would have made homesteading so much easier. The erecting of a hospital which has benefited our faithful doctor as much as the people who are ill.
